prompt:
Prompt: Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
Rubric for Patience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
essay:
Patience is a virtue that many people strive to embody in their daily lives. It is the ability to endure difficult situations without getting frustrated or complaining. A patient person remains calm and understanding, even when faced with challenging circumstances.

I have always admired my grandmother for her incredible patience. She never seems to lose her cool, no matter what obstacles come her way. One particular instance that stands out to me is when we were stuck in traffic on our way to a family gathering. It was raining heavily, and the roads were congested with cars.

Despite the stressful situation, my grandmother remained calm and composed. She simply turned on some soothing music and engaged me in a conversation about our plans for the day. Her ability to stay patient and positive in such a frustrating moment left a lasting impression on me.

I asked her how she managed to stay so patient, even in difficult circumstances. She simply smiled and said, "Life is full of unexpected challenges, and getting upset won't change the situation. It's better to focus on what we can control and make the best of it."

Her words resonated with me, and I realized the importance of patience in dealing with life's curveballs. Instead of getting worked up over things that are out of our hands, it is far more beneficial to remain patient and tackle the challenges with grace.

My grandmother's example has inspired me to work on my own patience. I now strive to approach difficult situations with a calm and understanding mindset. I have found that practicing patience has not only made me a more pleasant person to be around but has also helped me navigate through life's ups and downs with greater ease.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable quality that can help us navigate through life's uncertainties with grace and resilience. By emulating my grandmother's unwavering patience, I have learned to approach challenges with a level head and a positive attitude. Patience truly is a virtue worth cultivating.

essay:
One day, my friend Sally was really patient. She wanted to play with her new toy, but she had to wait for her mom to finish cooking dinner. Sally didn't complain or get mad, she just sat and waited quietly. She was understanding and tolerant of the situation.

While she was waiting, Sally helped her mom set the table and even entertained her little brother so her mom could finish cooking. She didn't get frustrated or lose her temper, she just stayed calm and waited for her turn to play with her toy.

When dinner was finally ready, Sally was so happy and grateful. She thanked her mom for the delicious meal and then happily played with her new toy. Her patience paid off and she had a great time playing with it.

I was so impressed by Sally's patience that day. She showed me that being patient is important and that good things come to those who wait. I learned a lot from her and I try to be more patient like she was that day.

essay:
Once upon a time there was a bear named Sally. She liked honey and playing in the woods. One day, Sally was walking in the woods and saw a squirrel. The squirrel was trying to climb a tree, but kept falling down. Sally decided to help the squirrel and waited patiently for it to try again.

The squirrel finally made it up the tree and was very happy. Sally felt good for helping the squirrel and they became friends. They played together every day and had lots of fun.

One day, Sally got very hungry and wanted some honey. She saw a beehive up in a tree and decided to climb up and get some. She waited patiently for the bees to buzz away and then climbed up the tree. But when she reached the hive, the bees came back and stung her. Sally started crying and ran away.

She learned that sometimes it's good to be patient, but also to be careful. And that's why she always asks her friend the squirrel for help when getting honey.

The end.

prompt:
Prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
Rubric for Laughter essay:

"6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter has always played a significant role in my relationship with my best friend, Sarah. We have known each other since we were in elementary school, and our bond has only grown stronger over the years. One particular memory that stands out to me is the time when we went on a road trip together last summer.

It was a spontaneous decision. We decided to pack our bags, jump into my old beat-up car, and just drive with no particular destination in mind. As we hit the open road, we blasted our favorite songs and sang along at the top of our lungs, not caring about who could hear us. Our voices may not have been the most melodious, but the laughter that ensued from our off-key singing was infectious.

Along the way, we encountered all sorts of mishaps - getting lost, running out of gas in the middle of nowhere, and having to rely on a questionable map that Sarah found buried in the glove compartment. Instead of panicking, we laughed it off. Our ability to find humor in even the most stressful situations was what kept us going.

One night, we found ourselves at a roadside diner in a small town. The food was mediocre at best, and the waitress seemed to be having a bad day. Our order was wrong, the milkshake was melted, and the coffee was lukewarm. Rather than getting upset, Sarah started making funny faces behind the waitress's back to make me laugh. Soon enough, we were both giggling uncontrollably, unable to contain our mirth.

That night, as we laid under the stars in a makeshift campsite, we were overcome with a sense of pure joy. The shared experiences, the inside jokes, and the memories we had created together had solidified our friendship even further. Our laughter had bridged the gap between us, making us feel closer than ever before.

As we drove back home, with the sun setting in the distance, I knew that this road trip had been more than just a getaway. It had reaffirmed the importance of laughter in our relationship. The ability to find humor in the mundane, to laugh in the face of adversity, and to share moments of pure joy - these were the foundations of our friendship.

In the end, someone once said that "laughter is the shortest distance between two people." In my case, laughter had not only brought me closer to Sarah but had also strengthened our bond in ways that words could never express. And for that, I am forever grateful.

essay:
One time, my friend Jimmy and I were at the park playing basketball. We were having so much fun shooting hoops and trying to make each other laugh. Jimmy tried to do a fancy trick shot and ended up missing the basket completely. I couldn't help but burst out laughing at how silly he looked trying to be all cool.

But then, when it was my turn to shoot, I accidentally threw the ball too hard and it hit the rim and bounced back and hit me on the head! Jimmy couldn't stop laughing at how clumsy I was. We were both rolling on the ground laughing so hard, our stomachs hurt.

After we finished playing basketball, we sat on a bench and talked about all the funny things that happened that day. We laughed so much that we attracted some looks from other people at the park. But we didn't care because we were having so much fun together.

That day, I realized how important laughter is in a friendship. It brings people closer together and creates memories that last a lifetime. Whenever I think back to the day at the park with Jimmy, I can't help but smile and laugh all over again. Laughter truly is the best medicine, especially when shared with a friend.

The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Once upon a time, me and my frend Sally was playing outside. We were runnnig around when we saw a funny looking clown. The clown was jumping all around and making silly faces. We started laffing so hard that our tummies hurt.

Sally said, "That clown is sooo funny! I wish I could have a red nose like him!" I agreed and said, "Yeah, we should ask him where he got his red nose from."

We ran up to the clown and asked him about his red nose. The clown looked at us and smiled. Then he pulled out a bunch of red foam noses and gave one to each of us. We put on the red noses and started acting silly like the clown.

We were jumping and dancing and making funny faces. The clown joined in and we were all laughing and having a great time. It was so much fun to be silly and laugh with the clown.

After a while, the clown had to go to his next show. We said goodbye and waved as he walked away. Sally and I took off our red noses but we kept laffing about all the funny things we did with the clown.

From that day on, whenever Sally and I felt sad or bored, we would put on our red noses and remember the silly clown. Laughter really is the best medicine and it helped us become better frends. Laughter brings people together and makes life more fun and enjoyable.

prompt:
Prompt: Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
essay:
During my sophomore year of high school, my best friend Sarah faced a major setback that tested her resilience. She had been working tirelessly to secure a spot on the varsity soccer team, pouring hours of practice and dedication into her goal. However, during the final tryouts, she suffered a devastating ankle injury that sidelined her for the entire season.

At first, Sarah was understandably disheartened. She had put so much of herself into achieving her dream, only to have it snatched away in an instant. Despite her initial disappointment, Sarah refused to give up. Instead of wallowing in self-pity, she focused on her recovery and rehabilitation with unwavering determination.

I watched in awe as Sarah tackled each physical therapy session with grit and resilience. She never once complained or expressed bitterness about her situation. Instead, she remained positive and hopeful, believing that she would come back stronger than ever.

As the season progressed without her, Sarah found other ways to stay connected to her team. She attended every practice and game, offering her encouragement and support from the sidelines. Her positive attitude and unwavering dedication inspired her teammates to push harder and persevere through their own challenges.

Finally, after months of hard work, Sarah was cleared to resume playing soccer. She returned to the field with a newfound appreciation for the game and a deeper sense of resilience. The setback had only made her stronger, both mentally and physically.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. She not only earned her spot back on the varsity team but also became a true leader and inspiration to her teammates. Her ability to bounce back from adversity with grace and determination taught me the true meaning of resilience and perseverance. I am immensely proud to call her my best friend and to have witnessed her incredible journey.

essay:
Once there was a boy named Timmy who loved to play soccer. He practiced every day after school and dreamed of one day playing for his school team. One day, during a big game, Timmy was injured and had to be taken to the hospital. The doctors told him he wouldn't be able to play soccer for a long time.

Timmy was devastated. He felt like his whole world had come crashing down. But instead of giving up, Timmy decided to use this setback as motivation to work even harder. He went to physical therapy every day and did everything the doctors told him to do.

Months went by, and Timmy slowly started to regain his strength. He started practicing soccer again, taking it slow at first but pushing himself more and more each day. Finally, after a year of hard work and determination, Timmy was back on the field playing the sport he loved.

Timmy's resilience and perseverance paid off. He never gave up, even when things seemed hopeless. He stayed strong, flexible, and optimistic throughout his recovery. Timmy's story is a reminder that no matter how tough things may seem, with resilience and determination, anything is possible.

essay:
Patience is a virtue that is often easier said than done. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure difficulties without complaint. While we all strive to be patient in our daily lives, it is not always easy to embody this quality. However, there are moments when we are put to the test and must rise to the occasion.

One such moment for me was when I was stuck in traffic on my way to an important job interview. I had left early to account for any unforeseen delays, but a massive accident had occurred on the highway, causing a major traffic jam. As the minutes turned into hours, I could feel my frustration and anxiety building. I was worried that I would miss my interview and ruin my chances of getting the job.

But instead of succumbing to my negative emotions, I took a deep breath and reminded myself to be patient. I couldn't control the traffic or the situation, but I could control how I reacted to it. I used the time stuck in traffic to go over my interview notes, practice my answers, and mentally prepare myself for the meeting ahead. Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the traffic began to move, and I arrived at the interview just in time.

I walked into the office feeling calm and collected, despite the stressful journey I had just endured. The hiring manager commented on how composed I seemed, even though I had been stuck in traffic for hours. I smiled and explained that I had learned the importance of patience and adaptability in challenging situations.

In the end, I aced the interview and got the job offer. Reflecting on that experience, I realized that being patient not only helped me stay calm in a stressful situation but also allowed me to make the most of a difficult circumstance. It is a lesson that I carry with me to this day, reminding me to stay composed and positive when faced with challenges.

Patience may not always come naturally, but it is a quality that can be developed and honed over time. By practicing understanding, tolerance, and resilience, we can navigate through life's obstacles with grace and composure. And ultimately, we may find that patience is not just a virtue but a valuable skill that can lead us to success in all areas of our lives.

essay:
Patience is a very important thing to have. It means you can wait for things without getting upset. I remember one time when I had to wait for my mom to finish at the store. She said it would only take a few minutes, but it felt like forever. I wanted to go home and play, but I knew I had to be patient.

I sat in the car and watched people walking by. I saw a dog running around and chasing a squirrel. It was funny to watch. I also saw a bird flying in the sky. It was pretty to see the different colors of its feathers.

Finally, my mom came out of the store. She said sorry for taking so long. I told her it was okay because I was patient. She was happy that I didn't get mad or start crying.

Being patient can be hard sometimes, but it is worth it. You can learn new things or see interesting stuff while waiting. It's important to be understanding and tolerant of others. That's what patience is all about.

essay:
One tyme I was waiting for my frend to play with me at the park. I was so exhited to see her because we had lots of fun together. But she was taking forevr to get there. I tried to wait patently but it was hard. I wated and wated but she still didn't come. I got mad and sad but then I remembered what my teacher told me about being patcent. So I tryed my hardest to be patcent and not get angrey. Finally, my frend showed up and we had the best day ever. Being patcent paid off in the end.

Being patcent is good because you don't want to get mad or angrey all the time. It is beter to wait and be nice. My mom is always patcent when I spill things or make a mess. She never yells at me and I am glad for that. I wish I could be more patcent like her.

My teacher says that being patcent is an important life skill to have. She says that being patcent can help us do better in skool and make more frends. I think she is rite. I will try to be more patcent from now on.

In konklusin, being patcent is verry impornat. It can help you have a better life and be a better person. Sometimes it is hard to wait but it is worth it in the end. Being patcent is good.

The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter is often said to be the universal language that brings people together. This sentiment was never more true to me than during a family vacation to the beach last summer. It was a trip that not only strengthened relationships, but also created lasting memories filled with joy and laughter.

One particular moment stands out in my mind when laughter played a significant role in our vacation. We were all gathered on the beach, enjoying the warm sun and cool ocean breeze. My younger cousin, who was only five years old at the time, decided that he wanted to build a sandcastle. Excitedly, he began scooping up sand and piling it into a mound.

As he worked diligently on his sandcastle, the rest of us watched with amusement. It was clear that he was determined to create a masterpiece, despite his limited experience in sandcastle construction. However, as he reached the top of his sandy creation, disaster struck. A rogue wave came crashing onto the shore, washing away his hard work in an instant.

At first, my cousin was devastated. He stood there in shock, staring at the remnants of his sandcastle being washed away by the tide. But then, something amazing happened. My uncle, always the one to lighten the mood, began making silly faces and cracking jokes. Slowly but surely, my cousin's frown turned into a smile. Before long, he was laughing along with the rest of us.

In that moment, I realized the true power of laughter in bringing people together. Despite the disappointment of losing his sandcastle, my cousin was able to find joy and comfort in the laughter of his family. It was a simple moment, but one that showed me how important humor and levity can be in fostering strong relationships.

As we walked back to our beach house that evening, the sound of our laughter filled the air. We shared stories, jokes, and memories that will stay with me forever. In the end, that vacation wasn't just about the sandy beaches and warm sun - it was about the laughter and love that connected us all.

Looking back on that trip, I am grateful for the relationships that were strengthened and the memories that were created. And I know that, no matter where life may take us, laughter will always be the shortest distance between us.
